verses.text: As he taught, Jesus said, "Watch out for the teachers of the law. They like to walk around in flowing robes and be greeted in the marketplaces,
and have the most important seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at banquets.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 12:38
rsbNotes.text: 12:38 Beware of the scribes. The superficiality of the scribes’ messianic doctrine and exegesis brings Jesus to criticize their superficial lifestyle in general. A similar warning is found in 8:15.

verses.text: They devour widows' houses and for a show make lengthy prayers. Such men will be punished most severely."

rsbNotes.title: Mark 12:40
rsbNotes.text:
12:40 devour widows’ houses. It was considered improper for anyone to receive a salary for interpreting the Scriptures. Consequently, they relied upon and sometimes took advantage of the hospitality of the people, among whom widows were especially vulnerable.

long prayers. See Matt. 6:5, 6 for a similar judgment of ostentatious and hypocritical spirituality.

verses.text: Jesus sat down opposite the place where the offerings were put and watched the crowd putting their money into the temple treasury. Many rich people threw in large amounts.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 12:41
rsbNotes.text: 12:41 treasury. The offering boxes were situated in the women’s court of the temple, which gave access to all.

verses.text: But a poor widow came and put in two very small copper coins, worth only a fraction of a penny.
Calling his disciples to him, Jesus said, "I tell you the truth, this poor widow has put more into the treasury than all the others.
They all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everything--all she had to live on."

rsbNotes.title: Mark 12:42
rsbNotes.text:
12:42 two small copper coins. This coin, the lepton, was the lowest denomination in circulation.

a penny. A Roman coin worth one sixty-fourth of a denarius (the denarius was one day’s wage). Mark translates into Greek for Gentile readers (5:41 note).

verses.text: As he was leaving the temple, one of his disciples said to him, "Look, Teacher! What massive stones! What magnificent buildings!"

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–37 This chapter is known as the “Little Apocalypse” or the Olivet Discourse. It makes predictions in three areas: the coming destruction of the temple (vv. 1–4); future persecutions (vv. 5–25); and the coming of the Son of Man (vv. 26–37).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:1
rsbNotes.text: 13:1 what wonderful stones and what wonderful buildings. Herod the Great began rebuilding the temple in 19 b.c., using marble and gold as decorative materials. The outer court measured five hundred by three hundred yards. It was bordered by walls of massive white stones, some of which were sixteen feet long and three to four feet high. On top of these were magnificent, covered cloisters or walkways with richly carved wooden ceilings.

verses.text: "Do you see all these great buildings?" replied Jesus. "Not one stone here will be left on another; every one will be thrown down."

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:2
rsbNotes.text: 13:2 one stone. Jerusalem was sacked and the temple burned and destroyed in a.d. 70 by Titus, the Roman general (later emperor). The Arch of Titus commemorating his victory still stands in Rome.

verses.text: As Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter, James, John and Andrew asked him privately,

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:3
rsbNotes.text: 13:3 Peter and James and John and Andrew asked him privately. Mark informs us that this teaching is part of the special instruction given to the Twelve (4:10, 11; 8:29).

verses.text: "Tell us, when will these things happen? And what will be the sign that they are all about to be fulfilled?"
Jesus said to them: "Watch out that no one deceives you.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:4
rsbNotes.text: 13:4 when will these things be. The disciples’ question has in view the predicted destruction of the temple. Jesus’ reply seems to include both this particular event and the time leading to the coming of the Son of Man (v. 26; cf. Matt. 24:3). The events surrounding the destruction of the temple seem to anticipate and typify those associated with the Second Coming.

verses.text: Many will come in my name, claiming, 'I am he,' and will deceive many.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:6
rsbNotes.text:
13:6 Many will come. In a.d. 130, Bar Kochba, the leader of a Jewish rebellion against the Romans, claimed to be and was accepted by his followers as the messiah, and the list has gone on since then.

I am he. This phrase is also the name of God (Ex. 3:14) and the title chosen by Jesus (John 8:28, 58).

verses.text: When you hear of wars and rumors of wars, do not be alarmed. Such things must happen, but the end is still to come.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:7
rsbNotes.text: 13:7 the end. According to the parallel text (Matt. 24:3), “the end” is “the close of the age.”

verses.text: Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places, and famines. These are the beginning of birth pains.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:8
rsbNotes.text: 13:8 birth pains. The Jews expected a time of suffering before the coming of the Messiah and described it in this way, as does Paul in Rom. 8:22.

verses.text: "You must be on your guard. You will be handed over to the local councils and flogged in the synagogues. On account of me you will stand before governors and kings as witnesses to them.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:9
rsbNotes.text: 13:9 councils. Synagogue councils had the right to order floggings, limited to forty strokes (Deut. 25:1–3). The apostles suffered imprisonments and floggings (Acts 4:21; 5:18, 40; 2 Cor. 6:9; 11:23, 24).

verses.text: And the gospel must first be preached to all nations.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:10
rsbNotes.text: 13:10 proclaimed to all nations. The time between the resurrection of Christ and His Second Coming is not simply a time of suffering and persecution, but a time of grace and of evangelism throughout the earth in fulfillment of the prophecy of Is. 49:6.

verses.text: Whenever you are arrested and brought to trial, do not worry beforehand about what to say. Just say whatever is given you at the time, for it is not you speaking, but the Holy Spirit.
"Brother will betray brother to death, and a father his child. Children will rebel against their parents and have them put to death.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:11
rsbNotes.text: 13:11 what you are to say. This is a promise of special assistance in time of need, rather than a reference to the ministry of the Spirit among the Twelve in establishing their proclamation of Jesus (John 14:25, 26; 15:26, 27; 16:12–15).

verses.text: All men will hate you because of me, but he who stands firm to the end will be saved.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 13:13
rsbNotes.text:
13:13 endures to the end. See note on v. 7. This statement may also mean the end of each person’s life. Such perseverance is often associated with suffering (Rom. 8:18–25; 12:12; Heb. 10:32; 12:2; 1 Pet. 2:20).

will be saved. Such steadfastness does not merit salvation but is the proof that true salvation, in one sense, has already taken place (Rom. 8:24).
